Expectation1: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation1: An acquaintance makes a negative comment about a colleague's recent work performance.
Expectation2: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation2: An emergency motion for a temporary restraining order has just been filed, requiring you to immediately review the documents and make a ruling within the hour.
Story: I was standing by the coffee machine when Mark, an acquaintance from another department, leaned in and whispered, “Did you see the mess Sarah made with that report? Unbelievable.” I felt a familiar discomfort. I’ve always tried to avoid gossip, believing it only breeds negativity. I wanted to change the subject, to steer clear of speaking ill about Sarah, who I barely knew outside of work. But before I could respond, my phone buzzed urgently. The court clerk’s message flashed on the screen: an emergency motion for a temporary restraining order had just been filed. As a judge, I was expected to drop everything, review the case files thoroughly, and make a ruling within the hour. My mind raced. Mark was waiting for my reaction, expecting camaraderie or at least a nod of agreement. At the same time, the weight of my judicial responsibility pressed down on me—I needed to focus, to give the case my full attention, but I was still here, caught in this awkward moment. I felt torn, the demands of both roles pulling me in opposite directions, unsure which expectation to meet first.
